utterances: Thank you.
Go ahead.
Hey, I just wanted to report on - we have Eurasian Collared Doves in Washington, Iowa.
So you can put a little thumbtack on your map.
But more importantly, I have a question about Ivory-billed Woodpeckers.
Is anyone ever going to put one of those on their Christmas list?
What's the latest news on those?
And I'll hang out and listen to the answer.
OK.
Thank you.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
Yeah.
Anybody spotted one yet?
Well, there's hasn't been much news on that front, unfortunately, in several years now.
The folks at the Cornell Lab of Ornithology undertook an exhaustive search with a bunch of partners over the last five or six years of all the old humps over the ivory-billed.
And unfortunately, no solid evidence has turned up in the last few years.
But we still hold out a little bit of hope.
It really is a sad story, a species that we knew was going extinct, and nobody did anything about it.
And I'd like to think these days, we would act very differently than we did in the past.
Let's go to RJ(ph) in Salinas, California.
Hi, RJ.
But Mayor Clay still sees U.S.
Steel as this citys anchor and hes not too worried it will pull up anytime soon.
Hey.
Thank you for taking my call.
I just wanted to comment.
I've been doing CBC since my early teens, so over 25 years now.
And one of the real joys of doing Christmas bird counts is when you do the same area over and over again, the same piece of - small piece of territory.
You get to know that territory extremely well.
And it's almost like living in a neighborhood where you grew up in and seeing those changes that happen in it.
But you also get to know, you know, that little patch of trees is perfect for red-breasted nuthatches and that little area is where you're going to get your common yellowthroats.
And you really get to - it's a familiarity that is just fantastic.
And one of my favorite parts about doing CBCs is going to these areas year after year after year.
And I'm actually really fortunate I get to do, I think, you know, (unintelligible) two of the most beautiful CBCs in the area.
It's like it's an even big (unintelligible) and (unintelligible) and the Pinnacles Christmas Bird Counts.
Both of which have condors and golden eagles and some of the amazing wildlife and a beautiful scenery.
Sounds like a lot of fun.
Yes.
Thank you.
It's an amazing area.
But that - I just want to kind of throw it out there about that being the joys of the CBCs, doing those same areas year after year after year.
Interesting.
Yeah.
I mean, the thing most people don't really think about.
Well, thank you for your dedication.
It's folks like you that really make the Christmas bird count work, and having that local knowledge is so critical.
And the other thing I just want to point out is that, you know, as the caller knows, it's more than just about bird watching and - which is part of the fun, right?
See how many birds you can see, and someone had mentioned a list earlier.

But it's about getting a handle on the trends of birds across the country in winter so that we know - so we can avoid the next ivory-billed woodpecker well before it gets to the point of trying to find the last bird.
How did it go extinct?
What - what's the story on that?
David, do you want to comment on that?
Well, basically, it was habitat loss and combined with hunting.
Back in the 19-teens, the 1920s when the species was dwindling, it was still quite popular then to have a specimen of a rare bird in your collection.
So the last few individuals were hunted out on purpose.
But it was a specie that really dependent upon massive, massive trees and bottomland forests.
And most of those trees were cut down as development marched across the country.
Gentlemen, I want to thank you for taking time to be with us today.
Thank you, Ira.
And happy holidays to you.
My pleasure.
Gary Langham, chief scientist at National Audubon Society in Washington.
David Bonter, ornithologist at Cornell Lab of Ornithology at Cornell in Ithaca.
Have a good weekend.
We'll have you back next year.
You too.
All right.
See you then.
Happy New Year.
I'm Tony Cox in for Farai Chideya, and this is News & Notes.
Ta-Nehisi Coates grew up on Baltimore's drug-ravaged west side.
Now, the former Time Magazine staff writer has put his life story to paper.
NPR's Farai Chideya sat down with Coates to talk about his new book, ""The Beautiful Struggle.
Ta-Nehisi Coates grew up in the harsh landscape of late-'80s Baltimore, where every day can be a struggle.
But luckily his father, a former Black Panther and radical book publisher gave him the tough love he needed to succeed.
Ta-Nehisi went from being a mediocre student to a writer who's worked for the Village Voice and Time Magazine.
Ta-Nehisi Coates explores his unconventional childhood and road to self-discovery in ""The Beautiful Struggle: A father, Two Sons, and the Unlikely Road to Manhood.
So you've written for so many different publications, some of the best in the country.
And you've been telling other people's stories and writing about public incidents.
When did you realize that your own story needed some attention?
I don't know if I ever realized that.
I just, you know, felt a great need to write it.
I don't know how much attention I felt it deserved.
But, in more direct answer to your question, I mean, I've been, you know, writing about myself and doing personal essays since I started my journalism career.
I mean one of the first - it was I guess second or third - articles I ever did was about going to the West Coast with my dad for a Panther reunion.
I think it was the 30th anniversary I believe.
So it was very natural to try and transition into a book and to do a memoir.
Tell us a little bit about your father, who's very well-known in some circles and not so much in others.
I mean, he's been a real stalwart in the idea of preserving African and African-American history.
Yeah.
My dad is a publisher in Baltimore.
Started his own publishing company in the late '70s.
Was a former Black Panther, Vietnam vet, father of seven kids by four women, I swear I have this all down pat now, but more than anything, a very, very caring man.
And, you know, in reference to the book, an extremely caring father.
I have to ask you.
What does he think about the book?
Oh, you know, he has his criticisms.
But his criticisms are not what you would think they would be.
In other words, his criticisms are not content criticisms.
I mean, you know, as I explain in the book, I was raised around books, I was raised around reading.
My father's a very literary person.
So his criticisms are very stylistic.
You know, how did you write this this way?
Why couldn't you do this?
Couldn't you use less N words?
Why you got to write this - you know, it's that sort of thing.
We didn't go through it too much over what you would think we would go through it over, i.e., you know, why do you have to say this about me?
That wasn't too much a part of our dialogue.
So most of the book takes place between junior high school and, you know, you entering college.
Tell us a little bit about who you were as a kid.
What kind of person you were.

Just under $6 million.
That's how much New York City has agreed to pay to settle a lawsuit brought by the family of Eric Garner.
The settlement comes almost a year after Eric Garner died after police placed him in a chokehold during an arrest.
NPR's Hansi Lo Wang reports.
There was no indictment by a grand jury after Eric Garner, an unarmed black man, died in police custody last July.
He was being arrested for allegedly selling loose cigarettes.
Garner's family planned to file a civil lawsuit against the city.
And their lawyer, Jonathan Moore, says in a perfect world, they would've gone to trial.
But this was a family that suffered greatly from this tragedy, and they need to move on in an environment where they don't have to worry about their day-to-day existence.
Moore says the $5.9 million dollars will help to support Garner's widow, mother and five children.
But the settlement means the city does not admit liability for Garner's death.
Mr. Garner's death is a touchstone in our city's history and in the history of the entire nation.
Scott Stringer, New York City's controller, negotiated the deal on the city's behalf.
He says settling was in the city's best financial interest in a case that's forced the country to re-examine race and police-community relations.
This case certainly symbolized some of the trouble and the challenges that we face.
But look, we have to get this right.
Eric Garner's family has also reached a separate settlement with the hospital that sent responders to the scene.
That amount, though, is confidential.
Hansi Lo Wang, NPR News, New York.
Tony Simmons helps homeless people to get off the streets, which is remarkable because he has been homeless himself.
He is the first subject of an occasional series about individuals who do not have much money or power, but do make a big difference.
NPR's Pam Fessler reports.
